title: Exostoses, Hearing Aids, and Brain Training
chief_complaint: I'm having slight difficulties hearing in daily situations, like hearing my wife, following conversations in social settings, and listening to the television.

problem_summary.course: Hearing thresholds remained stable over a decade, but speech-in-noise ability declined over time.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Bilateral exostoses (bony growths) in ear canals; history of noise exposure (Navy pilot).
problem_summary.functional_impact: Difficulty with soft speech and television; reduced processing speed and memory skills.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Interested in 'training his brain' to improve memory, focus, and processing speed.

history.present_illness: Patient presented at age 74 reporting slight hearing difficulties.
history.otologic_history: Avid swimmer in youth. Otoscopy revealed bilateral exostoses (Right > Left).
history.noise_exposure_history: Long history of noise exposure as a Navy pilot.
history.medical_psych_history: Negative for familial hearing loss or ototoxic medications.
history.patient_goals: Initially chose not to treat hearing loss.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Bilaterally symmetrical mild to moderate sensorineural hearing loss.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Word recognition testing in quiet at a comfortably loud level was within normal limits.

history.present_illness: Follow-up appointment; patient had not returned in 2001.
history.patient_goals: Preference for a custom-fit hearing aid that was 'less noticeable'.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Hearing loss found to be stable.

history.prior_management: Successful use of monaural Left CIC hearing aid (Right ear fit prevented by exostoses). Patient declined Right aid in 2004 and 2006.

tests.name: Speech-in-noise
tests.key_findings: QuickSIN performance was within normal limits.

history.present_illness: Reported wearing left CIC intermittently with decreasing benefit.
history.otologic_history: Exostoses appeared to have decreased in size bilaterally.

tests.name: Speech-in-noise
tests.key_findings: QuickSIN score decreased from normal to mild-to-moderate SNR loss.

numeric_results.QuickSIN Score: 5.5 dB SNR loss at 65 dB HL

history.present_illness: Monitoring progress with bilateral open-fit mini-BTEs and brain training.
history.prior_management: Averaging 10 hours of use per day with bilateral hearing aids. Completed ~40 brain training sessions per year.

tests.name: Speech-in-noise
tests.key_findings: Indicated a fairly stable SNR loss compared to 2009.

numeric_results.QuickSIN Score: 4.5 dB SNR loss at 55 dB HL

tests.name: Brain Training Performance
tests.key_findings: Showed improvement in processing speed, sound discrimination, and memory tasks over 4 years.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a long-standing, stable bilateral mild-to-moderate sensorineural hearing loss and a history of noise exposure. While pure-tone thresholds remained stable over a decade, speech-in-noise abilities (SNR loss) showed decline consistent with aging and auditory deprivation, moving from normal to mild-to-moderate loss. The patient has successfully transitioned from monaural CIC amplification to bilateral open-fit mini-BTEs, complemented by consistent auditory brain training.
counseling_points: Even if your hearing thresholds on the chart don't change, your brain's ability to process speech in noise can decline over time.
Using two hearing aids provides better support for your brain than just one, especially for understanding speech in noisy places.
Exostoses (surfer's ear) are benign, but they can complicate wearing certain types of custom hearing aids.
Auditory brain training exercises can help improve processing speed and memory, working alongside your hearing aids.
notes_for_actor: You are an 86-year-old former Navy pilot who used to be an avid swimmer.
You are motivated to maintain your cognitive health and are diligent about doing your 'brain exercises' on the computer.
Initially, you were vain about hearing aids (wanted 'less noticeable'), but you have become more accepting of behind-the-ear styles as you realized the benefit.
